issues.description: The Person.birthday attribute type differs between the problem statement / template and the solution. The problem's UML and the template common model declare birthday as java.time.LocalDate (Client-side code like PersonScene and controller expect LocalDate), but the solution's common Person model uses String for the birthday. This is a structural type mismatch that will confuse students (and cause JSON mapping/usage differences) because the rest of the template and the problem text use LocalDate.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the Person.birthday type consistent across all artifacts. Prefer keeping birthday as java.time.LocalDate to match the UML and the client UI (DatePicker). Update the solution's common Person model to use LocalDate (and adjust JSON (de)serialization if necessary), or alternatively update the template and problem statement to use String and update all client code accordingly. Ensure the chosen type is used consistently in Person, PersonService, PersonResource, and client classes.

issues.description: Within the solution repository there is an internal type inconsistency: the client UI (PersonScene) expects Person.getBirthday()/setBirthday(...) to work with java.time.LocalDate (it uses DatePicker and passes/reads LocalDate), but the solution's common Person model defines birthday as a String. This mismatch will cause compilation errors in the solution and is therefore an unintentional structural inconsistency.
issues.suggested_fix: Fix the solution so the client and the shared model agree on the type. Either change solution_repository's common Person.birthday back to LocalDate (recommended) or adapt the client code to convert between LocalDate and String at the UI boundary. After the change, recompile to ensure no type errors remain and update any (de)serialization configuration if needed.

issues.description: The problem statement's description of the controller method parameters contains a documentation/type mismatch: it says "Each method takes a Consumer<List<Note>> parameter... This consumer takes the internal list of persons as a parameter." The text incorrectly refers to Consumer<List<Note>> where it should state Consumer<List<Person>>. This inconsistent documentation could confuse students implementing the PersonController methods.
issues.suggested_fix: Correct the documentation in the problem statement to consistently refer to Consumer<List<Person>> for the PersonController methods so it matches the code and the intended design.
